Introduction

Esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) is a congenital condition resulting from failure of the primitive foregut to appropriately divide into separate and patent tracheal and esophageal structures.  Patients present immediately after birth with excessive oral secretions and choking, cough, or vomiting with feeding attempts.

Pathophysiology



At 4 weeks gestation, the trachea begins to develop from a diverticulum of the primitive foregut.  This tracheobronchial diverticulum lengthens and separates to form the respiratory tract, while the remaining portion becomes the esophagus.



Failure of the foregut to separate most commonly leads to esophageal atresia (ie, blind-ending pouch) and a fistula between the trachea and distal esophagus.  The underlying mechanism of this process is unknown but is likely multifactorial, involving genetic and environmental factors.

Classification



Esophageal atresia and TEF can present in various anatomic arrangements (

figure 1
), with the most common being esophageal atresia with a distal TEF.  Less common variations include esophageal atresia without TEF, esophageal atresia with a proximal or multiple TEFs, and the H-type TEF in which the fistula connects a patent esophagus (ie, no esophageal atresia) and trachea.



Esophageal atresia and/or TEF can be an isolated finding, but up to 50% of patients have other congenital abnormalities, such as:



  • VACTERL association:  Vertebral, Anal, Cardiac, TracheoEsophageal fistula, Renal, and/or Limb defects
  • CHARGE syndrome:  Coloboma, Heart defects, Atresia of choanae, Retardation of growth, Genitourinary anomalies, and Ear abnormalities

Clinical presentation



Signs and symptoms of the most common anatomic configuration (ie, esophageal atresia with a distal TEF) present immediately after birth and include the following (

figure 2
):



  • Excessive oral secretions/drooling due to an inability to swallow saliva
  • Choking, cough, or vomiting with feeding attempts
  • Respiratory distress and cyanosis from aspiration (
    figure 3
    ); aspiration can occur via reflux of gastric contents through the fistula or via reflux of esophageal pouch contents due to commonly associated esophageal dysmotility
  • Abdominal distension from air passing into the stomach from the trachea


Presentation of the less common H-type TEF can be insidious over months to years, particularly when the fistula is small, because the esophagus and trachea are fully patent.  However, due to aspiration through the fistula, history often reveals mild respiratory distress during feeding and recurrent respiratory tract infections.

Evaluation and diagnosis



Postnatal evaluation of suspected esophageal atresia with TEF includes the following:



  • Attempt at naso- or orogastric tube placement:  An inability to pass a feeding tube into the stomach due to resistance at the blind-ending pouch is consistent with esophageal atresia. 
  • X-ray (
    image 1
    ):  X-ray is used to visualize the tip of the catheter (which is often coiled) in the proximal esophagus, confirming the diagnosis.  X-ray may also reveal excessive air in the stomach and intestines. 
  • Esophagography with water-soluble contrast is performed if there is diagnostic uncertainty, revealing contrast that pools in the esophageal pouch.


Esophageal atresia and TEF may also be suspected on a routine prenatal ultrasound, which typically shows polyhydramnios due to the inability of the fetus to swallow amniotic fluid.

Differential diagnosis



  • Bilateral choanal atresia (
    figure 4
    ):  a congenital obstruction of the posterior nasal passages that presents with cyanosis during feeding and improves with crying.  Excessive drooling is not seen.  The inability to pass a nasogastric catheter through the nares is characteristic, but an orogastric tube would pass from the mouth through the esophagus and into the stomach.
  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia:  a displacement of abdominal viscera into the thoracic cavity that results in pulmonary dysplasia.  It presents with cyanosis and respiratory distress immediately after birth.  A scaphoid abdomen and auscultation of bowel sounds over the chest are appreciated on examination.  Characteristic x-ray findings include bowel in the thorax, a laterally shifted cardiac silhouette, and a gasless abdomen (
    image 2
    ).
  • Gastroesophageal reflux (
    figure 5
    ):  a regurgitation of gastric contents into the esophagus/oral cavity, commonly seen in healthy infants.  Coughing, respiratory distress during feeds, and resistance to feeding tube advancement are not seen.
  • Laryngomalacia (
    figure 6
    ):  a collapse of supraglottic structures during inspiration, presenting in infancy with inspiratory stridor.  Stridor is classically worse in the supine position and improves with upright positioning.  This condition is not associated with choking or coughing during feeds.
  • Critical congenital heart defects (eg, tetralogy of Fallot (
    figure 7
    )):  congenital cardiac lesions that often present with cyanosis shortly after birth.  An enteric tube would pass into the stomach with these conditions.

Management



Definitive treatment of esophageal atresia and tracheoesophageal fistula is surgical repair, including fistula ligation and anastomosis of the esophageal segments.



Echocardiography and renal ultrasonography should be performed to screen for additional congenital abnormalities (eg, VACTERL association).

Complications and prognosis 



The prognosis for surgically corrected esophageal atresia and tracheoesophageal fistula is favorable.  However, postoperative complications include stricture, anastomosis leak, and recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.  In addition, these patients have a higher risk of developing dysphagia, tracheomalacia, or esophageal cancer compared to the general population.

Summary



Esophageal atresia and tracheoesophageal fistula (
